text:
The Dyckman House, Broadway at the N.W. corner of 204th Street. This house was built early in the eighteenth century, and at the time of this photograph is not quite two hundred years old. The two wings are not a part of the original house, but were added during the 1860's. The house is falling into disrepair through long neglect, but it will soon be restored and converted into a museum, with the surrounding land a city park. The north wing will be demolished, but the south wing will stand as late as 1936, at which time it will be in use as a caretaker's residence.

1895.

Gift of John H. Judd.

(1)
Broadway, at the N.W. corner of West 204th (Hawthorne) Street. Frame building concerned is the old Dyckman House.

1932.

J. Clarence Davies, Collection, Museum of the City of New York.

(2)
A view of the same structure prior to rehabilitation.
1899.

Gift of Randall Comfort.

Gift of Randall Comfort.

Broadway, at the N. W. corner of West 204th Street, showing the old Dyckman House after restoration. It was built in the early 1700's and was partially destroyed by fire by the British in the Revolution. It was rebuilt and the family lived here until 1868 when it fell into disrepair. Presented to the City in 1915, it is now a museum.

Copyright by
Underwood & Underwood

Gift of Urbrock Collection

About 1920

West 204th (Hawthorne) Street, at the N.W. corner of Broadway. Frame building shown is the old Dyckman House, built in 1787.

October 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster, Collection.

Broadway, at the N. W. corner of West 204th Street, showing the Dyckman farmhouse, built 1787 by Wm. Dyckman. The original structure (burned by the British in the Revolutionary War) was erected by his grandfather, Jan Dyckman, the immigrant, in 1725. The family occupied it until 1868, and presented it to the City in 1915. A back porch destroyed in 1880 was restored, while the north wing, erected in 1830, was removed. This is a set of five views taken the same day.

October 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection

folder: Broadway - 204th Street, northwest corner, Manhattan, NY
title: Broadway - 204th Street, northwest corner

text:
Dyckman House. Broadway and East 204th Street, Manhattan. This is the only remaining farmhouse of the eighteenth century in Manhattan. Built in Dutch Colonial style William Dyckman in 1783, it replaced his earlier house on the same site which was destroyed during the Revolutionary War. In 1915, following restoration of the house and grounds, it was given to the City of New York by Dyckman's descendants.
Bank of New York Calendar 1967-68
